summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 6-12, 2020, between U.S. Attorney's Office staff and other officials, coordinating legal call access for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel while she was in custody at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) prior to her arraignment and bail hearing. It highlights logistical challenges and protocol discussions for attorney-client communications.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused individual in custody at MDC; defense counsel is attempting to schedule legal calls with her prior to her arraignment and bail hearing.

persons.name: Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell; the emails discuss scheduling standing legal calls for him to speak with his client.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge who directed the parties in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell to file a letter by 9pm on July 6, 2020, prompting the initial request for an emergency legal call.

connections.description: Everdell is identified as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, with emails focused on facilitating legal calls between them.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Arraignment and Bail Hearing
events.description: Scheduled court date for Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment and bail hearing, driving the urgency for pre-hearing attorney-client communication.

events.title: Judge Nathan's Order for Joint Letter
events.description: Judge Nathan directed the parties in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell to file a joint letter by 9pm, prompting an emergency request for a legal call between Maxwell and her defense counsel.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was in custody at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in July 2020, with her arraignment and bail hearing scheduled for July 14, 2020.
Her defense counsel faced difficulties scheduling legal calls with her, leading to coordination emails involving the U.S. Attorney's Office and MDC officials.
A protocol existed for inmates' counsel to request legal calls, but Maxwell's defense initially struggled with the process, requiring special accommodation for standing calls prior to her hearing.
Judge Nathan issued an order on July 6, 2020, for the parties to file a joint letter by 9pm, creating an urgent need for an attorney-client call that evening.
